text: Good afternoon, everybody.
Thank you for hanging in there with us.
I'm going to do something I haven't done

in about 20 years, which
is I'm actually going
to read the talk.
And I have to do it for this talk
for a number of reasons.
So, the title of this talk
is "A Master's Tool: The Leadership Life
and Legacy of Lewis Harwood Spence,"
who we all know as Harry.

"Is Harry Spence God? Or
is he just damn good?"

This was the headline
of an article published
in Boston Magazine in 1981,
describing the incredible impact

of Harry's work at the
Boston Housing Authority.

As Superior Court Judge
Paul Garrity later put it,

"Harry made tens of thousands
of apartments livable,

which prior to that
time had been unlivable.

He improved the quality
of life, housing-wise,
including security, for tens of thousands
of Boston citizens.
He focused on the people."
That was just one of Harry's many roles

in which Harry the leader
elevated the core mission
of the organization above glory,
ego, and personal ambition.
It became a pattern,

and he quickly became known
as the Turnaround King,
the go-to person for restoring function
and integrity to otherwise corrupt
and/or dysfunctional organizations.

So what I hope to do in
the five minutes remaining
is to present some of the basic elements
of Harry's theory of leadership
and cultural change in organizations based
on his many years

of experience fixing
broken public institutions,
and some ideas outlined in his writings.

Harry was in the midst of
writing a book when he died,

a book which focused on
his leadership philosophy

and approach across many
of the professional roles
that he held during his lifetime.

Apparently, he wanted to wait
until he was further along

before sharing these writings
with his wife, Robin Ely.

And we know Robin's a great
but very tough reviewer,

so Harry's like, "I can't
go half stepping to Robin."

So he came half stepping
to me, and I said,
"Harry, let's get it in shape."

He did share one of the early
theory chapters with me,
which I thought was fantastic,
and I was very generous and also gentle
with the feedback.

The central message had
to do with the primacy

of organizational mission
over personal ambition,
and the importance of attending
to the emotional well-being of employees.

One quote that stuck
with me and my students,

because Harry often guest
lectured in my classes,
and students loved him,
is that leaders have to attend
to the emotional life of the organization.
This means that leaders have to be able
to empathize with the emotional challenges

that employees faced, and
they needed to be able
to validate these experiences
while always seeking to build trust

in an understandably
mistrustful population.
In his own words, Harry believed that,
these are his words,

"As my experience of dysfunctional
organizations increased,"
this is from his chapter,

"I began to realize that
there was a meta-story
that characterized the history
of the descent into dysfunction.
In every organization,
the fundamental plot line was the same:

staff joined the organization
out of the belief in

and loyalty to the mission
of the organization.

They believed in providing
decent housing to the poor,

or protecting children
from abuse or neglect
or delivering justice to those seeking it.

They agreed to give up
a part of themselves
to the task of the organization,

and to spend their working
hours advancing that mission
in collaboration with others.

Their leaders exhorted
them to give their best
to the mission of the organization

and to believe that the
more they contributed
to the mission of the organization,
the more they would be rewarded.
But in every dysfunctional organization,
there came a point when the staff began
to feel swindled.

While the leadership of
the organization called

on everyone to commit
themselves wholeheartedly
to the mission of the organization,
staff began to see evidence
that the leadership themselves
sometimes put their personal self-interest
above this mission of the organization.

Leadership would prioritize
their own protection
or advancement ahead of the requirements

of the mission and would
compromise the mission

for the sake of their
own personal interests.

So suddenly, what had previously
seemed a moral enterprise
began to look more and more like a vehicle
for the aggrandizement of the leader.
What had felt like a collective calling
was revealed to be a sham,
nothing more than a delusion
behind which the leader's ego
enlisted the unwitting energies
of employees in a narcissistic project.
The employees withdrew their allegiance
from the organization
that had proven itself a counterfeit.

Their moral world collapsed
from the entire enterprise
down to a small circle of fellow employees

who still trusted each other
and had each other's backs.
Embittered to varying degrees,
the employees gave up any fealty
to the larger organization.

The sine qua non of an
effective organization,
a shared allegiance to the organization
and its mission, was gone.

Learning the specific narrative
of leadership betrayal
in your own organization,

as experienced and
recounted by your employees
is the first order of business
on entering an organization.
Knowing that story is essential

to winning back the
trust of the employees,

and restoring their
commitment to the organization
and its mission.

The employees need to know that
you understand the betrayal
that befell them,

often not just one betrayal
but multiple betrayals.
You assure them that you understand it
by repeating it back to them."
And then Harry writes,
"I never asked anyone to trust me.

I knew that request
treated employees as fools.

Given their experience
of the organization,

I told staff I understood they
had no reason to trust me.

I expected them to be
skeptical of my intentions,

and not to trust me until I
gave them concrete evidence
on which to base their trust.
Rebuilding a damaged relationship began

with acknowledging the
integrity of their experience
with assuring them that they were seen,
that they were heard,

that they were neither invisible,
nor taken for granted."
So part of the step
towards repairing this organizational harm
is what he calls the moral compact.

And that's the restoration of
organizational effectiveness
that he says, "The restoration
of organizational effectiveness begins
with the restoration of the moral compact.
What is the moral compact?
It is a universally shared agreement

that the efforts of every
member of the organization

will be directed to the
mission of the organization.

The most critical step to
restoring the moral compact
is to restore subordinates' confidence

in the sincerity of the leader's
commitment to the mission,
subordinates' confidence that the leader
will stay loyal to the mission,
even when her personal interests diverge
from the interests of the organization.

As a result, the fastest
and most effective way
to restore the moral compact
of the organization is also the riskiest.
It is for the leader of the organization
to publicly demonstrate a willingness
to take injury on himself or herself

in order to advance the
mission of the organization."
And Harry had experience with this.

"Every time the Boston
Herald excoriated me,"
he says the Boston Herald.
I guess that's an old newspaper,
maybe the Boston Globe.

Was there a Boston
Herald once upon a time?

- Yes.
- Okay.
Sorry, I just want to make sure.

"Every time the Boston
Herald excoriated me
as Commissioner of Child Welfare
for refusing to fire a social worker

who had made a thoughtful
and reasoned judgment
that had nonetheless ended in tragedy,
the confidence of the staff increased
that I was committed to the mission:

to ensuring that sound
judgment was not punishable

because fate had different
outcomes in store.
Constant and extensive communication

with the organization also
builds the foundations

of trust between an
organization and its leader.
I regularly wrote five or six-page letters
to all employees.

These letters laid out
the developing strategy
for change in the organization

and the values that
underlaid the strategy.
This constant communication
was a powerful antidote to betrayal."

And he says, "I have no idea
how widely my letters were read
but I believe that in treating employees
as capable partners

in the work of the
organization conveyed a trust

that was gradually
increasingly reciprocated.
In the end, you cannot expect
that every employee will agree
with every decision that you make,
but if you're able to lay out the grounds
for the decision,

and the integrity of
your reasoning process,
you will almost always win the respect,
if not the agreement of employees.
These grounds, or the raison d'Ãªtre,

of the organization are
constantly reinforced."
Harry argues that the real purpose
of weekly senior staff meetings

is not necessarily to engage
in group problem solving,
sometimes it is,

but more often, it's to
develop shared practice

in enacting the values
of the organization.

Every decision made in
senior staff meetings

is what he calls an exercise
in values clarification,
until the core values of the organization

are built into the muscle
memory of every single member
of the senior staff.

So the third thing that
I want to talk about,

the penultimate thing that I
found a little bit paradoxical
but very interesting

is that he argues that
the ultimate success
of the organization requires
a certain degree of disengagement.

Two of Harry's critical
principles of leadership
for change were that, number one,

human beings cannot
sustain a creative process
or creative approach to problems

without periodic meaningful
breaks from the problem, right?
So just as we as humans need sleep,
leaders need a break from the problem.
Secondly, an organization and its leaders
both know that the leader

cannot be an indispensable
presence in the organization

if the organization is ever
to become truly healthy.
So you can't develop a codependency.

Paradoxically, each of
these principles speaks
to the crucial importance of disengaging
from the organization

that seems to require our
unrelenting engagement.
Harry believed that, in his words,
"If you are committed to the mission,

you will want the
mission to be carried out

in perpetuity, not simply
during your own tenure.
If your ambitions are limited to success
during your own tenure,
you are, in fact, more committed

to your own success and
glory than to the mission.

Your task is not to lead
and manage brilliantly,
it is to weave the capacity
to pursue the mission into the very fabric
of the organization.
This is a wholly different understanding
of the leadership task than is usual.

Finally, I'm going to talk
about the myth of meritocracy

since the theme of this
conference is the master's tools
because I think, and Harry would say,
he would admit that much of his work
was facilitated by the fact

that he, in many ways,
embodied a master's tool.
Harry had the poise and polish of a prince
for those who knew him,

the politics of a hippie
and the power, potency,
and charisma of James Bond.
(audience chuckling)

He was a patrician in a
multi-generational Harvard legacy
that stretched back over a century.
His father, his grandfather,
he came from many lines of people
who attended this institution.
Harry was fully aware of his privilege
and how it might have enabled him
to weather battles and storms

that might have sunk or
destroyed the careers
of women and people of color.
But he was someone who used this power

to dismantle segments of the
master's house in his own way.

He has no illusions about
so-called meritocracy,
nor does he ignore the unfortunate impact
of politics on promotion
and its potential to undermine legitimacy.
So he says, quote,
"In theory, a meritocratic system ensures
that those who best advance the mission

of the organization
will themselves advance
within the organization.

But meritocracies rarely
work according to the ideal.
People advance for various reasons,

extraneous to the mission
of the organization:

political affiliations,
fealty to an ego-centric boss,
identity, in parentheses,

tall white males do better
on the promotional ladder
than anyone else."
And he was a very tall white male.
"Theatrics, any number of things.

All sorts of factors
other than effectiveness

in advancing the mission
enter into the equation.
The temptation to avail oneself

of these various
shortcuts is ever present.

"But when a leader," and this
is his cautionary message,
"When a leader seizes such a handhold,

it is apparent to everyone
in the organization.
Thereby undermining their own legitimacy."
So, you know, many of his insights,
although Harry spent an entire career
in the public sector,
his insights are not only applicable
to the public sector.

There are many lessons for
the private sector as well.
One thing that he argues continuously
is that we all have missions
that are meaningful to people,
whether it's educating children,
protecting people from harm,
providing essential housing,

or connecting people to
each other and the world.

Private companies need to
find a meaning, a purpose,

and there's a paper
written by Carla Tsampiras
on core purpose,
and connect that to the work
that they're doing day to day,
and affirm this commitment
and dedication to the social mission
and not just profit.

And that echoes some of the
talks that we heard earlier
about sort of redefining what it means
to be a good businessperson.
The second thing that he...
and there's many things,
but a second one that he says
that's near and dear to my heart,
and is integral to my PRESS model,
the R being root cause analysis,

is that in order to repair
organizational dysfunction,
you have to know what caused it.
Diagnosing the origins
of the organization's dysfunction
is the first order of business.
The best source of information
on what befell the organization
are the people who work there.

Constantly asking questions
of people at every level

of the organization
provides crucial information

on the history of the
organization and what went wrong.
So these are exit interviews

that surprisingly so
many companies don't do.
And interviewing people who were there.
So finally, I want to mention
that Harry wasn't just a god
but also an ordinary human being,
and a cherished husband, father,
and friend with a joie de vivre

and a deep gratitude for
the simple things in life.
This is a picture that I took
of Robin and Harry many years ago
while we were on vacation in Turkey.
And what I recall most,
aside from his constant smile
was his ability to marvel
at the beauty of simple things.
Despite his deep level of sophistication,

Harry would go on and on about
how fresh the cucumbers were

or how vibrant the hues
of the bougainvilleas

or the flowers adorning
people's houses were.

He loved the water and
swimming in the sea,
and he loved birds and watching,
and he could identify various species.
He's someone that I feel always had
a deep spiritual connection to the planet
that we inhabit,

whether it was the fruits
and flora of the Earth,
the wonder of its creatures
or the souls of its people.
Harry was present and connected.
That to me is the essence of grace.

Harry, thank you for
your warmth, your wisdom,
your courage and your contributions.
You've touched

the lives of many
people, including my own.
We're so grateful for your legacy.
Thank you.
